comment_text.mn135:1.1: This discourse has more parallels than any other Majjhima sutta: six in Chinese, two in Tibetan, two in Sanskrit, and fragments in Khotanese, Sogdian, and Tocharian. Its popularity is due to the detailed yet straightforward way it connects deeds with results, a subject of perennial fascination.
comment_text.mn135:4.1: This phrase is also explained at AN 10.216. In AN 5.57 it is one of five sayings that should be frequently recollected by “a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate”.
comment_text.mn135:5.1: The phrase “some woman or man” is used only here and in a few suttas that also deal with kamma (AN 3.70, AN 8.42, AN 8.43, AN 8.45). The mention of “woman or man” undercuts assumptions that women lack agency, or that their rebirth is lesser.
comment_text.mn135:5.3: Rebirth in the human realm is always due to good deeds in the past, but while in this realm, bad kamma can take effect. Of course, not all afflictions are caused by past kamma, a doctrine of the Jains that the Buddha rejected.
comment_text.mn135:8.1: A reason for one of the Buddha’s marks (DN 30:2.7.2).
comment_text.mn135:9.2: A person with a “mind like an open sore” (AN 3.25:1.6).
comment_text.mn135:10.4: The text switches from vaṇṇavanta (“beautiful”, MN 135:3.4) to pāsādika (“lovely”).
comment_text.mn135:15.2: The first three of these, phrased a little differently, are found at Pvr 7:51.1.
comment_text.mn135:17.1: This is the duty of a wheel-turning monarch (DN 26:5.6), as well as being a reason for one of the Buddha’s marks (DN 30:1.25.3).
comment_text.mn135:21.4: He went for refuge first in MN 99:28.4 and subsequently in DN 10:2.37.9.

root_text.mn135:2.1: Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn135:2.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn135:3.1: “Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo yena manussānaṁyeva sataṁ manussabhūtānaṁ dissanti hīnappaṇītatā?

root_text.mn135:4.1: “Kammassakā, māṇava, sattā kammadāyādā kammayonī kammabandhū kammappaṭisaraṇā.
root_text.mn135:4.4: “Na kho ahaṁ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājānāmi.
root_text.mn135:4.5: Sādhu me bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetu yathā ahaṁ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājāneyyan”ti.

root_text.mn135:4.7: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhagavato paccassosi.

root_text.mn135:21.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.

translation_text.mn135:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn135:2.1: Then the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn135:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn135:3.1: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?
translation_text.mn135:3.2: For people are seen who are short-lived and long-lived,
translation_text.mn135:3.9: What is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?”
translation_text.mn135:4.1: “Student, sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.
translation_text.mn135:4.2: It is deeds that divide beings into
translation_text.mn135:4.4: “I don’t understand the meaning of what the worthy Gotama has said in brief, without explaining the details.
translation_text.mn135:4.5: Worthy Gotama, please teach me this matter in detail so I can understand the meaning.”
translation_text.mn135:4.6: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn135:5.1: “Take some woman or man who kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn135:5.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn135:5.3: If they’re not reborn in a place of loss, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re short-lived.
translation_text.mn135:5.4: For killing living creatures is the path leading to a short lifespan.
translation_text.mn135:6.1: But take some woman or man who gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn135:6.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn135:6.3: If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re long-lived.
translation_text.mn135:6.4: For not killing living creatures is the path leading to a long lifespan.
translation_text.mn135:7.1: Take some woman or man who habitually hurts living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.
translation_text.mn135:7.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:7.3: or if they return to the human realm, they’re sickly …
translation_text.mn135:8.1: But take some woman or man who would never hurt living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.
translation_text.mn135:8.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
translation_text.mn135:8.3: or if they return to the human realm, they’re healthy …
translation_text.mn135:9.1: Take some woman or man who is irritable and bad-tempered.
translation_text.mn135:9.2: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
translation_text.mn135:9.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:9.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re ugly …
translation_text.mn135:10.1: But take some woman or man who isn’t irritable and bad-tempered.
translation_text.mn135:10.2: Even when heavily criticized, they don’t lose their temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
translation_text.mn135:10.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
translation_text.mn135:10.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re lovely …
translation_text.mn135:11.1: Take some woman or man who is jealous.
translation_text.mn135:11.2: They envy, resent, and begrudge the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others.
translation_text.mn135:11.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:11.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re insignificant …
translation_text.mn135:12.1: But take some woman or man who is not jealous …
translation_text.mn135:12.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
translation_text.mn135:12.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re illustrious …
translation_text.mn135:13.1: Take some woman or man who doesn’t give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
translation_text.mn135:13.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:13.3: or if they return to the human realm, they’re poor …
translation_text.mn135:14.1: But take some woman or man who does give to ascetics or brahmins …
translation_text.mn135:14.2: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
translation_text.mn135:14.3: or if they return to the human realm, they’re rich …
translation_text.mn135:15.1: Take some woman or man who is obstinate and arrogant.
translation_text.mn135:15.2: They don’t bow to those they should bow to. They don’t rise up for them, offer them a seat, make way for them, or honor, respect, esteem, or venerate those who are worthy of such.
translation_text.mn135:15.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:15.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in a low class family …
translation_text.mn135:16.1: But take some woman or man who is not obstinate and arrogant …
translation_text.mn135:16.3: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
translation_text.mn135:16.4: or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in an eminent family …
translation_text.mn135:17.1: Take some woman or man who doesn’t approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask:
translation_text.mn135:17.2: ‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful?
translation_text.mn135:17.3: What is blameworthy and what is blameless?
translation_text.mn135:17.4: What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated?
translation_text.mn135:17.5: What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’
translation_text.mn135:17.6: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
translation_text.mn135:17.7: or if they return to the human realm, they’re witless …
translation_text.mn135:18.1: But take some woman or man who does approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask:
translation_text.mn135:18.2: ‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful?
translation_text.mn135:18.3: What is blameworthy and what is blameless?
translation_text.mn135:18.4: What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated?
translation_text.mn135:18.5: What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’
translation_text.mn135:18.6: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn135:18.7: If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re very wise.
translation_text.mn135:18.8: For asking questions of ascetics or brahmins is the path leading to wisdom.
translation_text.mn135:19.1: So it is the way people live that makes them how they are, whether short-lived or long-lived,
translation_text.mn135:19.6: in a low class or eminent family,
translation_text.mn135:20.1: Sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.
translation_text.mn135:20.2: It is deeds that divide beings into
translation_text.mn135:21.1: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
translation_text.mn135:21.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn135:21.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn135:21.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
